question: Question_08
statement:
Prove that if \emph{p} is a prime number and \emph{p} \textgreater{} 4,
then

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
p^2 \equiv 1 \pmod 6\end{align*}
sols:
By saying that we look at primes larger than 4, what we really mean is
we look at all the primes except 2 and 3 (which makes sense since
2\textsuperscript{2} = 4 and 3\textsuperscript{2} = 9 which is 3 mod 6;
so these two don't work anyway).

Now any prime \emph{p} other than 2 and 3 will then clearly NOT be a
multiple of two and NOT be a multiple of 3. This means that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
p \equiv 1 \text{ or } 5 \pmod 6\end{align*} since integers that are 0, 2 or 4 mod
6 are all even and since an integer that is 3 mod 6 is a multiple of 3.

But since

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
1^2 \equiv 1 \pmod 6\end{align*} and

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
5^2 =25 \equiv 1 \pmod 6\end{align*}

we can conclude that if \emph{p} is a prime larger than 4, then its
square is always 1 mod 6.
